AphA Professional Registration Zoë Turner 2021-11-21 Chapter 1 Introductory notes The application Ill be first attempting is Senior Practitioner. I plan to outline some of the projects/analysis Ive worked on which include: Joining data across various clinical and non-clinical datasets to build up a complete dataset on patients who have died Venn diagrams to understand the SMI (Serious Mental Illness - a register held by GPs) and CPAs (Care Pathway Approach - for people in England with severe or complex mental health problems and those who may need services from a number of agencies to support them1 kept by the Trust) Smoking prevalence of Mental Health patients (both community and inpatients) compared to the ONS (Office of National Statistics) prevalence figures Improving and delivering the NHS-R Community Introduction to R and R Studio workshop Statistical analysis of surveys collected in the local Pride events Mainining an R package to access the SQL server data in a consistent and tidy way 1.1 Warnings Ive set this up by using the bookdown package and the template example from RStudio so for a bit it will look slightly odd as it will be my words followed by the template. I had to change the _output.yaml file to replace bookdown::pdf_book: with bookdown::html_book: and remove references to latex because of restrictions on my work laptop. I dont want to publish pdfs anyway because its not always accessible to screen readers so I dont really need that functionality. 1.2 Licence This is licenced under CCO and Im choosing to work openly on my registration as this is a collection of my knowledge and work that I feel can only benefit others if its shared. Most of it should already be on GitHub and if its not, it should be! 1.3 Motivations If I am successful in being accredited then I always wanted to share that learning so why not start early? And if I fail or get corrections, then we can learn from that too. 1.4 Information Governance Any data used in this registration will be generated synthetic data and the code to generate it will be available. I may change some code from the original to remove references to data structures that I do not own and have not had confirmed (yet) can be shared openly. 1.5 Corrections If you spot any mistakes, please do let me know through issues or email. Chapter 3 Standard 1 - Analytical approaches This standard relates to your involvement in the adoption and strategic decision-making in relation to the selection of analytical tools and techniques across your team and the wider organisation.. 3.1 SP1.1 Standard Commentary SP1.1 Identify which tools and techniques are most appropriate for the situation and justify the measures used. These situations will sometimes be non-routine although precedents are likely to have been established before within the team. Demonstrates a critical understanding (including researching) of the organisation and health care environment. What was the situation and analytical challenge? Which tools were available to complete the task? Which tool was selected and why? What were the benefits of using this particular tool? Where there any disadvantages? 3.1.1 Reflective Practice I was asked to find the smoking prevalence for mental health patients in the care of the Trust. Although smoking status had been recorded in two forms over the years the prevalence had never been calculated, only current smokers counted for CQUINs. Also, as the smoking status was not recorded regularly, to work out the yearly prevalence would require assuming smoking status for the years when they had an open referral but no smoking status recorded. I originally only had SQL and Excel as tools to complete this so I used SQL to combine data which counted: an assessment in a referral/inpatient stay an assessment before a referral/inpatient stay and assumed no change in smoking status in the interim period an assessment after a referral/inpatient stay and assumed no change SQL was the only way I could script this logic to make it reproducible but when I was asked to update this I moved to R as this is a more flexible analytical and statistical language. By moving the code to another language I validated my previous logic and I realised it was better to produce a row for each year between assessments and fill down the missing years. I also had mistakenly counted the ages based on the admission dates and, of course, everyone ages each year so I changed the age calculation to be on the first of every year. This isnt quite accurate but is much closer than my initial approach. I used RMarkdown to produce the workflow to bring the data together, including the ONS smoking prevalence data from their website, manipulate this to create a new dataset and the produce statistics from it. This meant I could write more narrative around the analysis which, when it was in SQL, was comments in the script and could not shared. The downside to using R was only that it takes longer than in SQL due to RAM needs and the function dplyr::fill() used to copy down information where it is missing took a long time; the dataset is a couple of million rows. I could get around this computational slowness by using a package called {data.table} which, whilst Im not familiar with, is much faster at processing data than my usual package of choice, {dplyr}. I used very little of the {data.table} code to ensure that I did not introduce any errors/bugs that I could not understand. 3.1.2 Evidence Provided Smoking prevalence report Code 3.2 SP1.2 Standard Commentary SP1.2 Have knowledge of a range of statistical/ numerical techniques, procedures acquired through qualification to degree level or equivalent relevant experience Identify statistical techniques being used. How did you get the knowledge of these techniques (formal learning, on-line resources, etc.)? 3.2.1 Reflective Practice For mortality surveillance I used SPC (statistical process control) charts but for much of the analysis of mortality, SPC is not appropriate because of patterns like seasonality or very small numbers (as in the case of suspected/confirmed suicides). For small number analysis I specifically chose to use time between charts in SPC, instead of count (xmr) or proportional charts for analysis as I wanted to see if there had been any decrease in the time between deaths as a pattern that should be monitored. The difficulty with these charts is conveying across to a audience who are familiar with SPCs that a point above the control limits is positive (in this context) as it relates to an increase in length of time between events. In order to check my reasoning on using these charts in this context I have presented my work at various analyst events. 3.2.2 Evidence Provided 3.2.2.1 Mortality I presented this particular presentation at: East Midlands AphA (Association of Professional Healthcare Analysts) branch meeting 1st November 2019 R-Ladies London 30th July 2019 NHS-R Community Conference 4-5th November 2019 lightning talk NHS-R Community I used this presentation to show how I had used R to create a mortality surveillance report. It is related to the Mortality surveillance slides in that this was the analysis part of the surveillance. Slides - link is to time interval chart SPC Code I did not study statistics formally but worked with colleagues to learn and apply statistical techniques in my work. 3.2.2.2 CPD 2021 Contributing to NHS-R Community, NHSRplotthedots package 2019 Introduction to R with statistics - Nottingham Trent University Internal statistics introduction course by Chris Beeley 2018 NHS-R Introduction to R and R Studio (with SPC) AphA Statistics day course, Leeds, 22 March 2018 (with John Varlow) 3.3 SP.1.3 Standard Commentary SP1.3 Be aware of the business questions that matter and how data fits with the organisation   How did you get a better understanding of the business requirements? Chapter 4 Standard 2  Critical Application This standard relates to your ability to select methods and apply these to analytical tasks. This should include the process undertaken from developing an analytical question to providing an outcome. 4.1 SP2.1 Standard Commentary SP2.1 Analyses considers the range of facts or situations requiring analysis What question prompted the analysis? What factors or situations could be impacting? How did you ensure your analysis was comprehensive and didnt just look at a single factor? 4.1.1 Reflective Practice 4.1.2 Evidence Provided 4.2 SP2.2 Standard Commentary SP2.2 Dealing with statistical/analytical queries, assessing whether analyses are robust eg investigating data anomalies identified during analyses, instigating corrective action as required. Did you encounter and problems during the analysis (e.g. data completeness, data quality issues etc.) and what did you do to address these? Did you deal with any questions or challenges as part of the task? 4.2.1 Reflective Practice 4.2.2 Evidence Provided 4.3 SP2.3 Standard Commentary SP2.3 Identifies potential issues and problems and escalates appropriately, and may recommend how these are addressed. What methods of analysis did you consider and why did you select your chosen methodology? Did you seek advice/guidance on methodologies? Did you talk through your approach with a peer? 4.3.1 Reflective Practice 4.3.2 Evidence Provided 4.4 SP2.4 Standard Commentary SP2.4 Decides on the appropriate methods to be used for the analysis. Will seek advice on more complex analyses or new (to the analyst) methods / tools. May provide guidance to others on which methods are used. How did you decide on your analytical method? Did you seek peer support or review for more complex or new methods of analysis? Do you support other with analytical methods? 4.4.1 Reflective Practice 4.4.2 Evidence Provided 4.5 SP2.5 Standard Commentary SP2.5 Expected to work reliably without supervision and where appropriate may supervise others Give examples of how you feel you work reliably without supervision. If you supervise others, how do you support them to work within a given framework? SP2.6 Expected result is defined, but decides how this is best achieved. What tools and methodologies did you use to perform the analysis and why? How did you arrive at the required output? 4.5.1 Reflective Practice 4.5.2 Evidence Provided 4.6 SP2.7 Standard Commentary SP2.7 Transform analytical insights into compelling business recommendations. How did you progress the results of your analysis into recommendations for your organisation? Describe how you applied your analytical results to the business question and what recommendations you made. How did you communicate these to the recipient of your analysis? 4.6.1 Reflective Practice 4.6.2 Evidence Provided 4.7 SP2.8 Standard Commentary SP2.8 Understandings (and communicates) strengths and limitations of data and appropriately addresses data quality issues What data quality issues have you dealt with, how have you dealt with these and how did you ensure data was interpreted correctly based on any limitations? 4.7.1 Reflective Practice 4.7.2 Evidence Provided 4.8 SP2.9 Standard Commentary SP2.9 Understandings (and communicates) strengths and limitations of analytical approach, can justify why chosen and analysis as a whole and proposes alternative methods that could be employed to overcome limitations in future work What analytical approaches did you consider and how did you select the one used? What were the strengths and limitations of the approaches? How did you communicate these to the recipient of your analysis?
